queue.title: Inside Europeâ€™s Economic Crises With Christine Lagarde | Leaders with Francine Lacqua
queue.description:
Francine Lacqua speaks to Christine Lagarde about Europeâ€™s economic travails, populism and how to lead through turbulent times. Lagarde, who served as managing director of the International Monetary Fund before becoming president of the European Central Bank, reflects on her response to the global financial crisis, the Eurozone debt crisis and bailout talks with Greece. 

In a widely varied career, she spent more than two decades practicing corporate law before being recruited as France's trade minister in 2005. She sits down with Lacqua in Frankfurt to reveal how she handles high-pressure situations, complex negotiations and dramatic change.

queue.title: We replaced our sales team with 20 AI agentsâ€”hereâ€™s what happened next | Jason Lemkin (SaaStr)
queue.description:
Jason Lemkin is the founder of SaaStr, the worldâ€™s largest community for software founders, and a veteran SaaS investor who has deployed over $200 million into B2B startups. After his last salesperson quit, Jason made a radical decision: replace his entire go-to-market team with AI agents. What started as an experiment has transformed into a new operating model, where 20 AI agents managed by just 1.2 humans now do the work previously handled by a team of 10 SDRs and AEs. queue.title: A Ponzi Schemer Freed by Trump Strikes Again
queue.description:
Eli Weinstein is a convicted fraudster who stole millions of dollars from investors at the height of the pandemic. He was able to do so because President Donald Trump during his first term commuted his 24-year sentence for a previous conviction. Now Weinstein is said to be planning to ask Trump for clemency again.

Within months of his release in 2021, Weinstein returned to scamming, stealing from unsuspecting victims until he was caught and convicted again, this time sentenced to 37 years in prison. While the administration contends it carefully weighs all petitions, the case points up what critics argue is a radical new system of how presidential clemency is granted, one where financial resources, connections and politics govern who goes free and who does not. 

Learn more: Freed by Trump, a $200 Million Fraudster Started a New Scam - https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2025-eli-weinstein-ponzi-fraud/?srnd=phx-bigtake

queue.title: 'Politics Can Be Brutal': Theresa May on Power and Populism | Leaders with Francine Lacqua
queue.description:
From Brexit and the European Union to global diplomacy, former UK Prime Minister Theresa May speaks with Francine Lacqua about her time at the pinnacle of British politics and her approach to leadership in a world she says often rewards the loudest voices. 

May reflects on her "steep learning curve" when former Conservative leader David Cameron appointed her home secretary, including having to respond to a series of terrorist attacks. 

May, who started her career at the Bank of England, also discusses the future of her own party at a time when Nigel Farage's right-wing Reform party is rising in the polls, and the threat Vladimir Putin poses to the world. "Strongmen," May says, cannot be allowed to proliferate at the expense of multilateral institutions.

queue.title: This Is How a 26-Year-Old Raised $108M in 1.5 Years | Reducto, Adit Abraham
queue.description:
How do you go from manually labeling document boxes to processing over a billion pages for the worldâ€™s top AI companies?

Adit Abraham is the Co-founder and CEO of Reducto, a Y Combinator (YC) alum that raised $108M from investors like Andreessen Horowitz and Benchmark. Reducto builds the infrastructure AI teams need to parse and extract complex, unstructured data.

In the early days, Adit did the "unsexy" work himself, from labeling data to manually setting up every single subscription. He views these repetitive tasks as a privilege because they mean the company is actually moving forward. In this video, Adit shares his journey from high school side hobbies to leading one of the fastest growing startup. 

This conversation is about the grit behind the growth, choosing hard problems, and why going off the beaten path leads to outlier outcomes.

Carina is a mathematician and the Founder and CEO of Axiom. She started the company at 24, and Axiom is building an AI Mathematician with a $64M seed round at a $300M valuation.

Through years of research, she developed strong taste and intuition for hard problems. In this video, Carina explains why AI Mathematicians matter. Math research involves long periods of being stuck. This conversation is about building in uncertainty, choosing hard problems, and amplifying human thinking instead of replacing it.

queue.title: How an 18-Year-Old High School Dropout Raised $6.2M | Nozomio, Arlan Rakhmetzhanov
queue.description:
Arlan shares the relentless persistence it takes to break into high-stakes environments, revealing the exact process he used to land an internship with the head of Venture Capital at Stanford.

Landing a dream role is rarely about an instant "yes." Instead, it is about the months of follow-ups, the refusal to be ignored, and the core belief that no door is permanently closed. Arlan breaks down the mindset of execution, arguing that the only difference between an average career and the scale of figures like Steve Jobs or Elon Musk is a commitment to curiosity and a refusal to self-limit.

This philosophy of "doing things that don't scale" and having "unreasonable determination" is exactly what Y Combinator co-founder Paul Graham looks for in world-class founders. In the world of YC, the most successful people are often those who refuse to take a "no" for an answer and continue to push through the noise until they get their seat at the table.

How do you operate at a global scale when you are starting from zero? Arlan shares a raw look at the power of determination, the art of the cold email, and why the biggest barrier to your success is often the one you have built in your own mind.

Key Insights:

Is the quantum computing bubble finally popping? IONQ stock recently lost 50% of its value from the recent peak back in mid-October. Of course, this is much too short of a time frame to make any meaningful conclusions, but it's still causing the degens to worry. Today, we'll discuss the reasons why IonQ stock crashed, including their absurd valuation and reliance on growth by acquisition. Is IONQ stock a buy? Let's find out.

queue.description:
IPOs are back, baby. Will the Grayscale IPO be a massive success, or a horrible failure? Today, we'll unpack Grayscale's business model, how they make money, and the risks they face. These risks include unreasonably high expense ratios, growing competition from the likes of BlackRock, and - oh yeah, no revenue growth.
